Live now: The Baltimore City Council votes on a historic $15/hr minimum wage measure. It is expected to pass and will give workers a $15 min wage in 2022. Businesses with fewer than 50 employees won't reach $15/hr until 2026.

status_message:
Raising Voices Film Series is designed to inspire community dialogues and explore brave and creative subjects through documentary films. 

Join us every 3rd Thursday for free film-screenings and live panel discussion at the Real News Network Studios in downtown Baltimore.

Next Screening: The Homestretch

Produced and directed by Anne de Mare and Kirsten Kelly

"The Homestretch follows three homeless teens as they fight to stay in school, graduate, and build a future. Each of these smart, ambitious teenagers - Roque, Kasey and Anthony - will surprise, inspire, and challenge audiences to rethink stereotypes of homelessness as they work to complete their education while facing the trauma of being alone and abandoned at an early age.

Through haunting images, intimate scenes, and first-person narratives, these teens take us on their journeys of struggle and triumph. As their stories unfold, the film connects us deeply with larger issues of poverty, race, juvenile justice, immigration, foster care, and LGBTQ rights." - Homestretch Film website

Featured Artists: Wide Angle Youth Media film short: A Cry For  Hope

Post Screening Panel:
Ciera Dunlap & Essence Jacobs - YES Homeless Youth Drop in Center
Marisela Gomez - Community Activist
Jeff Singer - Healthcare for the Homeless
link_name: Raising Voices Film Series ft. The Homestretch

status_message:
Join us every 3rd Thursday for free film-screenings and live panel discussion at the Real News Network Studios in downtown Baltimore.

The series kicks off with a screening of 3 1/2 Minutes, 10 Bullets, an award winning documentary film that explores the shooting death of Jordan Davis, an African-American teen who was killed by Michael Dunn, middle-aged white man. The shooting was sparked by an argument between Dunn and Davis over loud rap music. The film examines the incident as well as the subsequent trial, media coverage and protests that resulted from the shooting.

Admission is free. Seating is limited. Reserve your seats on Eventbrite.
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/raising-voices-film-series-feat-3-12-minutes-10-bullets-tickets-29417891706
link_name: 3 1/2 Minutes: Ten Bullets - Film Screening

status_message:

Watch the full story here: http://bit.ly/2if43ZG
link_name: Is the Baltimore Police Union Running the City?

TRNN journalists Taya Graham and Stephen Janis have started an Indiegogo campaign to turn their expansive coverage of the issue facing the town of Pocomoke, MD into a full fledged documentary. The film will explore law enforcement, race, and politics, revealing America's conflicting beliefs of how communities of color should and can be policed. The conflict stems from the firing of the first African-American police chief in Pocomoke, and the subsequent court case. 

Please make a donation to help make the documentary become a reality:

status_message:
Here's raw footage from Oct 27th 2016. The day where over 120 people were arrested and faced police brutality, when asked to leave the North Camp also known as Treaty Land. 
Many people were sprayed with mace, shot with rubber bullets, and hit by flash grenades. One man was shot in the face with a taser.  
Horse riders were shot pointblank range, horses were injured one even one died.
Police also entered and desecrated American Indian burial grounds, where protectors stood to defend.
This same day DAPL security fired a gun into a crowd of Protecters. BIA also known as The Bureau of Indian Affairs were called to arrest him.

status_message:
We invite you to join us in a town hall on Oct 26th to discuss what real police reform looks like. The recent Department of Justice report on the Baltimore City Police Department exposed the rampant abuse many in Baltimore know well, but many think it fell short of offering real solutions to end this abuse through accountability. 

What does real community control of the police look like? Why are officers so infrequently jailed, or even fired, for abuse? Can you reform the police department from within? How do you deal with police reform without dealing with chronic poverty, low wages, and the war on drugs?

Activists, elected officials and candidates, scholars, police officers and other Baltimore residents will discuss and debate how to affect real change. We'll look into what the DOJ and other government bodies can do, and what communities can do right now. We'll also examine the role of police in society, and what we want that role to be.

Let's come up with real solutions to make the police department accountable to the people of Baltimore, and respect people's constitutional rights.

If you can't make the event in person you can check it out on www.TRNN.com, where it will be livestreamed.
link_name: What does REAL Police Reform look like? :: A TRNN Town Hall

WATCH NOW! The full documentary on the Koch Brothers' War on Climate Science: http://therealnews.com/the-doubt-machine

Please take a moment to LIKE and SHARE this post and visit our website for more information: http://therealnews.com/the-doubt-machine

Several months ago, investigative journalist Bruce Livesey produced a documentary about the Koch brothers for Global News. The film focused on the Koch's vast holdings in Alberta's controversial tar sands, their campaign to deny climate change, and their political influence. But days before the video was set to air, executives at Global News pulled it from their broadcast schedule and Bruce was fired.

Bruce has teamed up with The Real News Network to expose the Koch brothers' war on the environment and their plan to buy the 2016 elections. We have raised half the money needed to produce and distribute the documentary, we need your help to raise the remaining funds needed and finish making the film.

Visit our website for more information: http://bit.ly/1OEsZyU

One of the more surreal moments of the DNC: 

Roger Ailes walks into our studio in the media pavilion, shakes Paul Jay's hand, then puts his hand on the shoulder of one of our female staff and turns back to Paul and says "always remember be nice to the ladies."  He had no idea who Paul or TRNN are, just a photo op of some sort for a documentary film. This is from the man who created the Fox News conservative juggernaut and was recently dismissed from Fox amid allegations of sexual harassment. Life is weird.

status_message:
The Real News Network is proud to present a panel discussion on "What is a Canadian, Anyway?" Joined by members of Toronto's Black Lives Matter, First Nations activists, and Sharmini Peries of The Real News, Paul Jay will be moderating a conversation on what it means to be part of a marginalized community in a country that touts its multi-cultural identity.

The panelists will also be discussing the growth of ally-ship between the varying groups and how this is strengthening all the movements.

Panelists will include:

Janaya Khan  Black Lives Matter
Sharmini Peries  The Real News Network
Jamaias DaCosta - The Vibe Collective and Indigenous Waves Radio

Date: June 21, 2016
Location: Studio Bar, 824 Dundas St W, Toronto, ON

Time: Event starts at 7:30PM doors Open at 7:00PM

                        **Pay what you can**
link_name: What is a Canadian, Anyway?

status_message: A confederate statue erected during the nadir of race relations in the US will remain on the courthouse lawn in Talbot County, MD. The Talbot council voted 5-0 to keep the statue which the NAACP asked the council to remove. In his speech before the vote Talbot County Council President Corey Pack likened the statue to a Nazi death camp which should be preserved as a reminder of past atrocities. But NAACP President Richard Potter disagreed, arguing a statue on a courthouse law commemorating slavery symbolizes something entirely different.
link_name: Confederate Statue in Talbot County MD

status_message:
The Maryland Board of Elections has decertified the results of the Baltimore city mayoral primary which last week declared Catherine Pugh the winner. State officials made the decision to investigate reported irregularities after voters complained of lack of absentee ballots, precincts opening late, and results that were lost for up to twenty four hours.  

Watch TRNN's in-depth coverage of the concerns: http://bit.ly/1NWOcul
link_name: Baltimore Election Under Intense Scrutiny

status_message:
FREE Movie Screening, 5/19 at 6:30pm! Followed by a panel discussion with Eddie Conway. RSVP @ https://www.facebook.com/events/1134365089938097/

Malcolm X, one of the most enigmatic and prolific civil rights figures in American history is once again brought to life through the documentary X: The Final Years. Narrated by former Black Panther Eddie Conway, X delves into the last years of Malcolm's life, his transition from religious to political thought after his break with the Nation of Islam, his transformation through his travels abroad - and ultimately what the legacy he left behind means for the continuing civil rights fight of today.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Democratic voters are heading to the polls today in Alaska, Hawaii and Washington State. To catch up to Hillary Clinton, Bernie Sanders would need to continue winning such states by wide margins like he did in Idaho and Utah Tuesday night. 

In a recent report, award winning-author Robert McChesney told us: 

"People are just learning about Bernie Sanders in large parts of the country. It's their first introduction to him. And it's a very positive one. So the future, the immediate future, looks great. Saturday he will likely win blowout wins in Hawaii and Alaska, and Washington State, which is a large state. So then he'll have five consecutive blowout 20, 30, 40-point victories over Hillary Clinton in races going into the all-important Wisconsin race." 


Watch and read more below:
link_name: Corporate Media Tries to Bury Sanders Before He's Dead

status_message: BREAKING: Maryland's Court of Appeals, its highest court, has overturned previous decisions and ruled officer William Porter (below, left) must testify against his five fellow officers who are his co-defendants for the death of Freddie Gray. After Porter's trial ended in a mistrial in December, prosecutors granted him immunity for his testimony against his fellow officers but Porter's attorney's argued he should not be compelled to testify. Click below to watch our report from January featuring dueling perspectives on Judge Barry William's initial ruling, which was later blocked by a higher court and finally upheld today. http://bit.ly/1mCUi79
link_name: Judge Orders William Porter To Testify in Trial of Fellow Officers in Freddie Gray Case

status_message:
WATCH NOW! The full documentary on the Koch Brothers' War on Climate Science: http://therealnews.com/the-doubt-machine

Please take a moment to LIKE and SHARE this post and visit our website for more information: http://therealnews.com/the-doubt-machine

If you watched last week's #Demdebate, you likely caught Bernie Sanders's statement about the Koch brothers' influence on politics. Despite this kind of national exposure, still too few people are aware of the Koch brothers and their current efforts to buy the White House. Together, we can change that. 

Several months ago, investigative journalist Bruce Livesey produced a documentary about the Koch brothers for Global News. The film focused on the Koch's vast holdings in Alberta's controversial tar sands, their campaign to deny climate change, and their political influence. But days before the video was set to air, executives at Global News pulled it from their broadcast schedule and Bruce was fired. 

Today, Bruce is teaming up with The Real News Network to expose the Koch brothers' war on the environment and their plan to buy the 2016 presidential election - and we need your help. Visit our website for more information: http://bit.ly/1OEsZyU
link_name: The documentary the Koch brothers don't want you to see

status_message: NEW DEVELOPMENTS in a story of a Baltimore community's fight to prevent the devastating environmental consequences of a planned incinerator. Residents of Curtis Bay in Southwest Baltimore have filed an notice to sue Energy Answers International which has been planning to build the facility that would pump hundreds of pounds of lead and mercury into the atmosphere. The filing is the first step towards further legal efforts to block the incinerator which has been in the works since 2009. We spoke to Destiny Watford of Free Your Voice about the ongoing controversy. Click here to watch our in-depth coverage of the issue: http://bit.ly/1WrAIpR
link_name: 7 Arrested Demanding State Revoke Permit for New Baltimore Inc...

status_message:
Can you tell us of another time something like this has happened before? In tonight's Democratic Debate, Presidential Candidate Bernie Sanders ripped into Hillary Clinton's close ties with Henry Kissinger. Here is what he said, and in the link below you watch and read what Wikileaks taught us about his legacy. 

"Where the Secretary and I have a very profound difference...she talked about the approval or support or the mentoring of Henry Kissinger. Now I find it rather amazing. Because I happen to believe that Kissinger was one of the most destructive secretaries of state in the modern history of this country. I am proud to say that Henry Kissinger is not my friend. I will not take advice from Henry Kissinger. And in fact, Kissinger's actions in Cambodia, when the United States bombed that country...created the instability that allowed Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge to come in and butcher 3 million people  one of the worst genocides in the history of the world. So count me in as someone who will not be listening to Henry Kissinger."- Bernie Sanders
link_name: Wikileaks Releases Kissinger Cables and Two Decisions in Manning Trial

status_message:
HAPPENING NOW: Visit www.therealnews.com as we stream live from the #NHprimary to cut through the flash and spectacle surrounding the presidential race.

We need your help to get the word out. Please like and share this post and like The Real News Network for updates.

Why?

Because after Iowa, it's even more apparent that mainstream media has no interest in providing a critical context for citizens seeking to make a deeply informed decision about the presidential elections.

Monopoly media stands in defense of the status quo. Corporate-owned television networks - liberal and conservative - treat grave problems as mere background for sham political theatre. No wonder: they sell at least $11.4 billion a year in political advertising.

Be it war and the destruction of whole societies, catastrophic consequences of climate change, chronic poverty and the ravaging of workers' living standards, or systemic racism and mass incarceration - all of the candidates in the primaries should be judged on how they will address these issues.

With your support, we will observe the media-marginalized Sanders campaign and highlight the substantive differences between Sanders and Clinton, a distinction the major news networks have failed to make. We will dig into the ideas of Trump, Cruz, and Rubio and examine how such policies will affect the lives of working people. Live from the Media Center and on the street, live from a Sanders rally to challenging interviews with Trump supporters, we will give you a view of the process you won't see anywhere else.

BREAKING NEWS:  Maryland Delegate Dan Morhaim is taking aim at the war on drugs.  Today he announced sweeping proposals to decriminalize possession of small amounts of heroin and cocaine in Maryland, and create safe zones where people can use drugs without fear of arrest.  He also wants to require treatment on demand in the state.   Neil Franklin, a former narcotics commander and now a member of LEAP (Law Enforcement Officers Against Prohibition) showing support for ending the drug war which he says is destroying communities like Baltimore
link_name: Maryland Advocates Take Aim at the War on Drugs

status_message: BREAKING NEWS:  Three African-American police officers have filed a federal civil rights lawsuit against the city of Pocomoke MD.  The lawsuit alleges city officials retaliated against the officers after they filed an EEOC complaint recounting harassment from white officers in a Worcester County special enforcement unit.  The lawsuit details how city officials pressured and ultimately fired Chief Kelvin Sewell for refusing to terminate the officer who initially filed the complaint.  The Real News has been covering the story in depth, click on this link to see our ongoing coverage and check back later for a full story on the lawsuit and it's implications.
link_name: Black Police Chief Makes Community Policing Work...Then Gets Fired

"This is very typical, the way in which the Mexican government has been approaching this whole issue, in terms of making sort of public shows of trying to get El Chapo Guzman, but then letting him go." - John Mill Ackerman

John Mill Ackerman says the real problem facing the rule of law in Mexico is Obama's blind support for the Nieto government.
link_name: El Chapo Arrest Won't Change Narco-Governance in Mexico

status_message:
"We had babies from two years old and people in their 80s out there all together as one because - it was us against the police. So when Jesse Jackson and them came down we didn't want their support. Because, I mean, they can't relate to us." - Rika Tyler

In this episode of teleSUR's Days of Revolt, Chris Hedges sits down with two activists from Ferguson's Hands Up United, Rika Tyler and T-Dubb-O, to discuss the oppression of Black people in and around Ferguson, and the importance of international solidarity in the fight for racial justice.
link_name: Days of Revolt: The New Black Militants

status_message:
"I felt it was time to do something more. And in terms of writing, in terms of running for a judgeship, I think that I can make changes in the system and bring a different perspective that we don't have right now." - Todd Oppenheim

Todd Oppenheim who is running for circuit court judge says judges have the power to alleviate some of the most entrenched inequities in the city's legal system.
link_name: Candidate: Judges Can Reform Baltimore's Unequal Justice System

status_message:
"Parents and the community have to come together to support our teachers. Our children are our future, so the fight right now is about receiving a quality education." - Stephanie Beal

link_name: Detroit Teachers Shutdown Public Schools in Protest of Deplorable Conditions

status_message:
"Today you cannot understand this mania about guns without understanding the fact that there is a right-wing movement that is rising that even certain mainstream Republicans say carry a whiff of fascism about them." - Gerald Horne

Historian Gerald Horne tracks the evolution of the gun debate starting from slavery during the country's founding, the post-Civil War reconstruction in the south, and through today's era of mass incarceration.
link_name: The Racist History of the 2nd Amendment and Why it Matters Today

status_message: A Baltimore commission has recommended removing two confederate monuments in the city.   The panel wants a statue of  Roger B. Taney the architect of the Dred Scott decision removed from Mt. Vernon.  The group also voted to remove a monument depicting Robert E.  Lee and Stonewall Jackson removed form Wyman park.   Two other monuments will remain with added context.   For more info on the historical background and the ongoing debate watch our coverage here.
link_name: Baltimore Still Debating What to Do With Confederate Statues

status_message:
The next phase of the trials for six officers charged with the death of Freddie Gray resumed this morning.

On the docket today were pretrial motions for the Ceasar Goodson the driver of the van in which Gray was fatally injured. Goodson faces the most serious charges of 2nd degree depraved heart murder, and his case could prove critical for prosecutors, particularly after Officer William Porter's trial ended in mistrial last month.
In today's motions judge Barry Williams ruled:
-Judge ruled the jury in the Goodson trial will be anonymous but not sequestered (similar to the Porter Trial)
-Judge will allow testimony of asst. chief Medical Examiner who conducted autopsy of Freddie Gray. Defense objected, saying her conclusion Gray's death was a homicide and preventable was out of the scope of her expertise.
- Judge also ruled testimony regarding
-The jury will be allowed to view the wagon Freddie Gray was transported in during the trial
- Major Neill Franklin a former chief trainer of the Baltimore police department will be allowed as an expert witness for the prosecution. The defense had argued Franklin's interviews on the Freddie Gray case showed he was a biased witness. But Judge Williams found Franklin only provided those interviews before he was hired as an expert witness. You can watch our latest interview with Maj. Franklin below.
link_name: Former Baltimore Police Trainer: Porter Responsible for Freddie Gray's Death

His major supporters were the maroons....what that demonstrates is the importance of the maroons in the history of the interaction between Europeans in the Americas...without the maroons, we might not have heard of Drake."

On this weeks episode of teleSUR's The Global African, Dr. Msomi Moor and Dr. Sheila Walker discuss the legacy of the Maroon presence in Panama and Colombia.
link_name: Sheltering Liberation: A Short History of Maroon Settlements

status_message:

status_message:
"Bill Clinton, Hillary Clinton have said they don't want to bring back Glass-Steagall even though it was immensely successful, and even though we can see when you don't have that general rule and you have to rely on specific, partial provisions, it's easy to evade and it's even easier to chip away at. And this was a big chip, a $10 trillion chip, that they've already taken out of Dodd-Frank."

After Congress rammed through a 'cromnibus' spending bill last year that repealed parts of Dodd-Frank financial regulation, UMKC's Bill Black explains how with or without this repeal another Wall Street bailout is still a real possibility.
link_name: Warren Investigation Finds Taxpayers Could Be on the Hook for $10 Trillion in Risky Derivatives

They were just notified in the middle of the night or early morning, and then sent off to this secretive unit without explanation. When they asked for some opportunity to appeal their designation, or some explanation for what has happened and why they're there, they were either ignored or answered in very simplistic terms, and not really elaborated."

"It had a definite chastening and deadening effect on academic inquiry and political expression. And what happened was, I think, the worst part of it, was that once that got into the air, it became normal. You accepted those things really unconsciously."

status_message:
"More than a year ago the city realized it did not have a non-discrimination ordinance, a local remedy to protect everyone.Most major cities have some sort of local remedy for discrimination many states have this as well.Houston had zero."

Dr. Maria Gonzales, Associate Professor of English at the University of Houston and screening chair for the Houston GLBT Political Caucus, says the vote in Houston against LGBT equality is a new version of the old anti-"scary" people trope.

status_message:
"Quantitative easing...is really just a fancy word for the Federal Reserve printing money, buying various kinds of financial assets with the hope that the financial asset values would go up...But it didn't quite work out that way."

Gerald Epstein is codirector of the Political Economy Research Institute (PERI) and Professor of Economics.
link_name: New Research Says Income Inequality Worsened Under Fed's Quantitative Easing Policy

status_message:
"TransCanada already, as we speak, has a pipeline that goes from the Alberta tar sands down to the Gulf Coast. So when you see all these news stories popping up in the business press, the mainstream media, and all over the place, you see the Keystone XL described as a pipeline that goes from Alberta down to the Gulf Coast. Well, they already have that." 

DeSmogBlog's Steve Horn says the pipeline company Enbridge is still planning a $5 billion terminal expansion. Note: After the publication of this story, the State Department announced it rejected TransCanada's request to suspend its review of the Keystone XL pipeline.
link_name: Keystone XL Delay is Celebrated, But Tar Sands Oil Will Still Flow to the Gulf

"All the prisoners I've talked to were transferred to the CMU without any warning. They were just notified in the middle of the night or early morning, and then sent off to this secretive unit without explanation. When they asked for some opportunity to appeal their designation, or some explanation for what has happened and why they're there, they were either ignored or answered in very simplistic terms, and not really elaborated."

Investigative journalist Will Potter discusses his recent coverage of secret FBI prisons and the use of CMUs (Communication Management Units) to punish prisoners, which is both excessive and illegal.
link_name: 'Little Guantanamos' in the United States

"[The] extent of the clashes that we see now is much larger than we've seen in several years now, and it could easily deteriorate into a third intifada by the mere fact that the Israeli government is actually stoking the flames by using, by making no effort to address the causes, but just using punitive measures." - Shir Hever

Economist Shir Hever comes on to discuss Israel's recent crackdown on protesters and explains why more repression will not subdue the anger stemming from decades of occupation.

"All the prisoners I've talked to were transferred to the CMU without any warning. When they asked for some opportunity to appeal their designation, or some explanation for what has happened and why they're there, they were either ignored or answered in very simplistic terms, and not really elaborated."

Investigative journalist Will Potter discusses his recent coverage of secret FBI prisons and the use of CMUs (Communication Management Units) to punish prisoners, which is both excessive and illegal.

status_message:
"This is a country which is endowed with a large number of natural resources, including oil. But also a large economy, which means that basically the country is punching below its weight in terms of provision of social services to its population." - Leonce Ndikumana

Leonce Ndikumana says economies like Nigeria, that are bountiful in resources, require reformed tax codes if they want to make real impacts on poverty.
link_name: Did the UN Meet Its 2015 Water & Sanitation Goals for Sub-Saharan Africa?

status_message:
"Our culture now is vastly different...And what is really so different is you had certain expectations that became a kind of major premise of life in the post-war period, especially the '40s, '50s, '60s, '70s. And then suddenly you have a very radical, revolutionary change in the political economy. You have a sudden massive concentration of wealth, power, pleasure and leisure right at the very top. And really, no outlet for it. You have sort of a mass culture saying that all this is wonderful and great. And if you're not participating in it, you're alienated that much more." - Mark Ames

Mark Ames, Journalist and Senior Editor at PandoDaily explains what measures, including the Reagan years and beyond have aided in creating the hostile work environment that potentially leads to more mass shootings in workplaces and schools.
link_name: What The Changing Workplace Has to Do With Mass Shootings

status_message: New: The Empire Files with Abby Martin. The Empire has a range of weapons to maintain its power: from its courts to its military. But it also has effective ideological weapons. Watch more on teleSUR
link_name: America's Unofficial Religion - The War on an Idea

status_message: "There's a certain amount of money that's just disguised bribes to doctors. And consulting fees on clinical trials that is really just about getting favor with doctors that prescribe your products. All of that's good from a commercial point of view but it doesn't really do anything for medical outcomes." - Jamie Love
link_name: Why Drug Prices Are Out of Control, And What We Can Do About It

status_message:
"The honest and realistic thing is to say, look, we need much more fundamental change and no matter how uncomfortable that makes people who are committed to the status quo if you don't do that you are fiddling around with policies that are no longer adequate to the level of economic problem we have." - Richard Wolff

UMass Amherst's Richard Wolff is on to discuss why labor force participation is the lowest since 1977 and what's really needed to stimulate the economy.
link_name: 38% of American Workforce Still Jobless

status_message:
"The more questions that we ask, and the answers to those questions will not be pretty, will not be convincing, I think, the more illumination we can bring to this benighted ideology and this regime." - Omer Aziz

Omer Aziz, J.D. candidate at Yale University, says the Saudis are blocking an inquiry into one of the worst humanitarian disasters in recent times.
link_name: Saudi Arabia Silences UN Human Rights Council Over Its War Crimes in Yemen (2/2)

status_message: "Obama has called the TPP the most progressive trade agreement in our nation's history, citing its strong environmental and labor protection laws. But Perez-Rocha says that there's a very different narrative abroad, where not only workers, environmentalists, and activists among others are resisting the TPP, but companies, too." - Thomas Hedges
link_name: What Washington Isn't Saying About the TPP 'Victory'

status_message:
"With the Russians more heavily involved...they have more influence in Damascus. If they're interested in negotiations then they may be able to get Assad to genuinely talk during negotiations."

Patrick Cockburn, whom Seymour Hersh called, "quite simply, the best Western journalist at work in Iraq today", joins us after just returning from Syria. In this interview he addresses some of the more complex issues Syria now faces and offers some scenarios of life after Assad.
link_name: A Syria Without Assad?

status_message: "[The] extent of the clashes that we see now is much larger than we've seen in several years now, and it could easily deteriorate into a third intifada by the mere fact that the Israeli government is actually stoking the flames by using, by making no effort to address the causes, but just using punitive measures." - Shir Hever
link_name: Israel Escalates Punitive Measures Against Palestinian Resistance in Jerusalem

status_message:
"They're waiting for us in the developed world to say all right, we caused 75 percent of this problem. We're going to contribute to the Green Climate Fund." - Andrew Jones

Andrew Jones, co-founder and co-director of Climate Interactive and Chris Williams, environmental activist and author of Ecology and Socialism, join us to discuss the recent UN pledges to cut emissions. Our panel covers the reality of these commitments, over 130 countries pledged, China being the largest, and the road blocks to averting climate disaster.
link_name: Countdown to Paris: Are the Pledges to Cut Emissions Enough to Save the Planet?

status_message:
"Our goal is to bring a shift in the balance of social forces in Greece, and to bring exactly all of those changes that are necessary for the social majority, for the working people actually to improve their life and to change...their position...within society."

Stathis Kouvelakis, member of Popular Unity, says the SYRIZA capitulation to creditors was followed by a voter turnout of 44%, the lowest in the country's history.
link_name: Defeat and Demoralization in Greece

status_message: "That's something that Canadians and other people around the world don't realize, is that Canada is a major player in the international arms trade, a producer and exporter of military goods around the world. This is not a new thing. This is not a new thing at all. Canada has been in the top ten or twelve military exporters for many decades" - Richard Sanders, founder of the Coalition to Oppose the Arms Trade.
link_name: Opposition Party Leaders Avoid Canada's Role in Global Arms Trade and Wars

status_message: "If you need to end exploitation--that should be the endgame. And our view is that the social surplus that the working-class produces must be redistributed among those work it, and in the best interests of society, and to advance humanity, rather than to advance greed." - Irvin Jim
link_name: At the Center of a Storm - Irvin Jim on RAI (3/3)

status_message:
"The more questions that we ask, and the answers to those questions will not be pretty, will not be convincing, I think, the more illumination we can bring to this benighted ideology and this regime." - Omer Aziz

status_message: "As more and more foreign forces on all sides go in, whether it's bombers, whether it's foreign troops, it makes the situation worse for Syrians on the ground. That's the bad news. The Russians bombing is going to kill more civilians just like U.S. bombing is going to kill civilians. This is not a war that has a military solution." - Phyllis Bennis
link_name: Russians Could Force New Negotiations Over Syria

status_message:
"90 percent of Walmart distribution centers are built with your tax dollars, and so are, it appears, about a third of Walmart stores. Home Depot, Lowe's, shopping centers, Cabela's, they all build their stores with your tax dollars that they take from the local schools and the police and the fire department."

In Part 4, David Cay Johnston speaks about the mismanagement of public funds for private gain and how our elected officials are making a world for future generations that will be much worse off.
link_name: Pillaging the Public Treasury - David Cay Johnston on Reality Asserts Itself (4/4)

status_message:
"It is basically the U.S. and NATO and also the Afghan military investigating their own misconduct, and the allegations against themselves for a possible war crime." - Sune Engel Rasmussen

Sune Engel Rasmussen is a reporter for The Guardian in Kabul, Afghanistan. She describes the local reaction to the bombing and questions the verification process that the US military exercises before bombing targets.
link_name: MSF Demands War Crime Probe in Afghanistan

status_message: "I had not been in certain communities in Baltimore City my entire life, and I've been introduced to those communities since I've been here in January. And the poverty--you wouldn't think that a community like that would still exist in this country, quite frankly. The housing, the poverty, the drug addictions, the hopelessness." - Baltimore City Police Commissioner Kevin Davis on poverty in the city.
link_name: Baltimore Police Commissioner Stunned by Poverty in Baltimore

status_message: "Yemenis are dying at a rate of 30 per day. This is one of the poorest countries in the Middle East and in the world that's being bombarded from the sky." Omer Aziz speaks with TRNN about the humanitarian situation in Yemen.
link_name: Saudi Arabia Silences UN Human Rights Council Over Its War Crimes in Yemen (1/2)

Pulitzer Prize winning journalist David Cay Johnston on his time covering the LAPD for the LA Times.

status_message: "3 months ago this exact hospital was attacked by Afghan military forces. link_name: MSF Hospital Targeted by Afghan Government Forces in July

status_message: "The reality of the situation is that Tsipras and his government had it easy so far, so to say. They have totally surrendered the sovereignty of the country to the lenders." - Stathis Kouvelakis
link_name: The Future of Popular Unity in Greece (2/2)

status_message:
"I was in the most exciting position to me, and being with people I admired and looked up to and I'd read about and now here I was in this movement. I had no idea when I first got there it was about to explode."

In the first part of our interview with Kathleen Cleaver, she talks about her activist parents, her introduction to the civil rights movement, black liberation and her thrill at joining SNCC (Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee). TRNN's Eddie Conway and Dominque Stevenson present this unique peak in to the life of this great leader and activist.
link_name: Evolution of A Black Panther (1/2)

status_message: "This city arrested 100,000 people a year for about seven years under Martin O'Malley as mayor. I don't think anyone can really understand the trauma of that type of policy. "Maryland has what's called a Correctional Officers' Bill of Rights, which when correctional officers are accused of any wrongdoing, they themselves, and their people who are attached to them, have the sole right to pursue that investigation. So you can't have an outside investigation come in. You literally have COs and police policing COs and police."

Lawrence Grandpre, Director of Research for The Leaders of a Beautiful Struggle, discusses the case of Darrell Murray, the incarcerated and slain brother of a fellow activist.
link_name: Another Suspicious Death Raises More Concerns About Black Life Behind Bars

status_message:
"The war on drugs has been a total failure...and I was on that war on drugs...U.S. Marshal and DEA. And I brought up the issue oftentimes of how the disparities in the war on drugs were simply going after one race of people...it was going after people of color, and I saw it. I raised the issue oftentimes and was always told, look, we go to the weakest link. We go to the areas where we can get our numbers up."

Today we speak with Matthew Fogg, a retired 32-year veteran Chief Deputy U.S. Federal Marshal. Fogg says that drug prohibition is an immoral tool used by the United States' prison industrial complex to maintain the largest per capita rate of incarcerations in the world.
link_name: Proposed Sentencing Reforms Would Keep Drug War Policies Intact

status_message:
"I don't think that the United States has ever wanted Syria to stay in place unless...it does so with a dictator that is sympathetic to U.S. interests." - Jennifer Loewenstein

We continue our discussion with Jennifer Loewenstein, faculty associate in Middle Eastern Studies at Penn State University and Joseph Daher, PhD candidate at the University of Lucerne in Switzerland. Joseph argues that the U.S. has never genuinely attempted to depose Assad and has in fact poured most of its resources in to fighting ISIS, instead of supporting democratic forces.
link_name: Inter-Imperial Feuds and the Lost Revolution in Syria (2/2)

Sami Ramadani: The US and allied regional powers pushed early militarization of struggle as outside powers tried to control the outcome of the Syrian revolution.

link_name: The Politics of Politics: Grace Lee Boggs Remembered

status_message:
"What I'm more concerned about are the equity questions...we've seen...the closing of over 100 schools in several cities, and over 25 schools in many cities in the U.S., and the privatization of those schools. Turning them over to charter school operators. And this has been devastating to low-income communities of color around the country." - Pauline Lipman

We were joined by Professor Pauline Lipman and educator Jose Luis Vilson to discuss the legacy of Arne Duncan, U.S. Secretary of Education and what we know about his successor John B. King.
link_name: Privatization, Charters & High-Stakes Tests: Arne Duncan's Legacy

And seeming to have a set position on criminal justice reform is now expedient for him." - Glen Ford of the Black Agenda Report
link_name: A Critical Look at VICE's Story on Mass Imprisonment with Obama and Holder

status_message:
"The war on drugs has been a total failure...and I was on that war on drugs...U.S. Marshal and DEA. And I brought up the issue oftentimes of how the disparities in the war on drugs were simply going after one race of people...it was going after people of color, and I saw it. I raised the issue oftentimes and was always told, look, we go to the weakest link. We go to the areas where we can get our numbers up."

Today we speak with Matthew Fogg, a retired 32-year veteran Chief Deputy U.S. Federal Marshal. He's a member of Law Enforcement Against Prohibition (LEAP). He was recently elected to the position of second vice president of Blacks In Government (BIG). Fogg says that drug prohibition is an immoral tool used by the United States' prison industrial complex to maintain the largest per capita rate of incarcerations in the world.

status_message:
From Actvism Munich: Glenn Greenwald on the Corporate Media, Propaganda & Reactions to Edward Snowden's Revelations (1/3)

"We knew that the primary weapon that the United States government and its allies would use to try and attack our reporting and attack what we're doing, was to use these media outlets that are very deferential to governments, are very close with governments. They pretend to be adversarial to them, they pretend to be watchdogs over them - but what they really do is disseminate their propaganda.

And we did get attacked by journalists in the United States and the UK particularly, which is really kind of remarkable - this is an act of pure journalism, every journalist in the world should have been cheering Edward Snowden, he did what every journalist is supposed to be devoted to, which is shining a light on what the most powerful factions are doing in the dark."

In this video acTVism Munich asks Glenn Greenwald at a Press Conference in Munich his opinion on the Mainstream Corporate Media and their reaction towards the NSA disclosures brought to light by whistleblower, Edward Snowden. Furthermore, Greenwald talks about the significance of the preparations that he undertook with Laura Poitras and Edward Snowden before they decided to go public with the highly-classifed NSA documents. The next two parts of this press conference with Greenwald will be released soon."

INFO: In this video Actvism Munich asks Glenn Greenwald at a Press Conference in Munich, his opinion on the Mainstream Corporate Media and their reaction towards the NSA disclosures brought to light by whistleblower, Edward Snowden. Furthermore, Greenwald talks about the signficance of the preparations that he undertook with Laura Poitras and Edward Snowden before they decided to go public with the highly-classifed NSA documents. The next two parts of this press conference with Greenwald will be released soon.

Picture copyrights & credits to: Laura Poitras
link_name: VIDEO: Glenn Greenwald Interview Mnchen

status_message:
"I don't think that the United States has ever wanted Syria to stay in place unless...it does so with a dictator that is sympathetic to U.S. interests." - Jennifer Loewenstein

link_name: Inter-Imperial Feuds and the Lost Revolution in Syria (2/2)

status_message:
"The war on drugs has been a total failure...and I was on that war on drugs...U.S. Marshal and DEA. And I brought up the issue oftentimes of how the disparities in the war on drugs were simply going after one race of people...it was going after people of color, and I saw it. I raised the issue oftentimes and was always told, look, we go to the weakest link. We go to the areas where we can get our numbers up."

Today we speak with Matthew Fogg, a retired 32-year veteran Chief Deputy U.S. Federal Marshal. He's a member of Law Enforcement Against Prohibition (LEAP). He was recently elected to the position of second vice president of Blacks In Government (BIG). Fogg says that drug prohibition is an immoral tool used by the United States' prison industrial complex to maintain the largest per capita rate of incarcerations in the world.
link_name: Proposed Sentencing Reforms Would Keep Drug War Policies Intact

status_message:
"The commercial banks are now holding $2.5 trillion in cash. They get the money for free because the interest rate is zero. They're holding the equivalent of 15 percent of U.S. GDP in cash. And they're not lending it out. The whole point of the policy is not just for the banks to accumulate cash, but to lend it." - Robert Pollin

Robert Pollin says the Federal Reserve has the tools to promote credit expansion for productive investment and create jobs for 22 million people who are currently out of work.
link_name: Beyond Zero Interest Rate Policy: How the Fed Can Stimulate the Economy

status_message:
"We're all Greeks now and we're all having austerity rammed down our throat. We're reconfiguring the global economy into a kind of form of neo-feudalism. So what does it mean to have revolution?" - Chris Hedges

In this episode of teleSUR's Days of Revolt, host Chris Hedges sits down with author and professor Leo Panitch to discuss how global imperialism and capitalism are upheld by economic and cultural forces, and debate the roles of ignorance, myth, and malevolence in the perpetuation of systems of inequality. Join the debate here and let us know what you think.
link_name: Days of Revolt: The Making of Global Capitalism

status_message:
"We want to stop the killing. We want to stop the now increasing destabilization of some key allies by all these refugees that are heading out of Syria. We want to get the situation under control, stabilize it, and somehow turn it around so it's more positive. It also will impact Iraq. It will impact Afghanistan. And ultimately it will impact this growing rapprochement with Iran, which can handle a lot more of these problems." - Col. Lawrence Wilkerson

Col. Lawrence Wilkerson tells Paul Jay that cooperation with Russia and Iran is the only way to resolve the situation, but U.S. policy is catering to Saudi Arabian, Turkish and Israeli ambitions.
link_name: Is the U.S. Secretly Welcoming Increased Russian Syria Involvement?

"The saddest example is a woman named Candice Anderson, she's in Texas. She lost control of her Saturn and ran into a tree, killing her fiancee. And she was charged with reckless homicide for that accident. And it turned out later that the car had a defective switch, and the judge expunged all of her criminal record, but not before her parents had to liquidate their retirement account to pay for her defense."

Professor Rena Steinzor on one of the 124 deaths tied to the corporation's faulty ignition switches, for which General Motors agreed to pay a $900 million settlement.

"The Soviet experience has shown that this internally centralized kind of uniform planning doesn't work. On the other hand, it's not as if there is any real-world economy that is not planned at all."

In Part 7, Ha-Joon Chang explains that despite the fall of communism, we are in fact living in planned economies.
link_name: 23 Things They Don't Tell You About Capitalism Pt.7

status_message:
"The thing I remember the most is...how mentally oppressive life can be there. Feeling that everything about your life, the air that you breathe, the water that you drink, when you can turn the electricity on or off, what sorts of food are available to you, where and how you can move in and out of your own home, are all being controlled by an outside force."

This week on Days of Revolt, Chris Hedges sits down with Laila el-Haddad, activist and co-author of Gaza Unsilenced, to discuss the psychological repression of Gaza's youth by Israeli state violence and occupation.
link_name: Israel's War on Children

status_message:
"The Catholic church, going back to the long tenure of John Paul II, pushed out thousands of vocations, of priests, sisters, brothers, layworkers, who acknowledged the truth about global income disparity and the rapacious nature of capitalism, especially in the developing world. And by doing so they empowered an extremely right-wing elite centered around groups like Opus Dei, which saw even the acknowledgement of that reality as a kind of heresy."

Chris Hedges talks with Paul Jay about Pope Francis shifting the church back onto a ground where it at least speaks about the reality that a very large constituency of the Catholic church faces every day.
link_name: A Progressive Pope or Greenwashing the Vatican?

status_message: Abby Martin interviews Chris Hedges on American myths, war and revolt. Hedges explains the 'folly of Empire,' the dangers posed by right-wing extremism and the urgent need for a new system.
link_name: Abby Martin & Chris Hedges: War, Propaganda and the Enemy Within

status_message: "The murder and disappearance of 43 students represents the Mexican reality. It represents the clandestine graves in all the country, it represents all the massive human [mutilations] that have been occurring on the coattails of the displaced populations, people from the violence." - Ame Vera, activist in the student movement in Mexico City with Perspectiva Criticas, on the level of frustration and the kind of organizing that is going on in the city at the moment.
link_name: Parents Stage Hunger Strike to Demand Answers One Year After Disappearance of 43 Mexican Students

status_message:
"It's another example of a system that has failed us. We see it every day in our patients. They're the ones that suffer. The system has failed us. It's rigged. And when people say, you know, why would somebody do what this company did, I always answer the same: because they can. There's nothing to stop them."

We're joined by Jean Ross, co-president of National Nurses United. She discusses the institutional context behind the recent overnight price hike of Daraprim.
link_name: Price Gouging In Health Care Is The Rule, Not the Exception

status_message: "He toned down his language from the more explicit anti-capitalist language that he's used in the past. But I think the message stood out loud and clear, that the economic system that we've created is one that leads to the exploitative nature that leads to social exclusion, that leads to a whole series of evils that are plaguing the planet." - Medea Benjamin
link_name: Is the Pope a Man of the Left?

status_message:
"He's saying that if we are going to get any kind of ecological justice [or] change to protect the planet, we can only do so if we get social change at the same time." - Chris Williams

Paul Jay chats with Author Nancy Scheper-Hughes and Professor Chris Williams on Pope Francis' criticism of finance, climate change and call to end capital punishment.
link_name: The Pope Mutes Message in Congress Speech

status_message:
"What's good about what the Pope is saying is, he's linking the ecological damage caused by capitalism to the social effects caused by capitalism and we have to solve both questions at once." - Chris Williams

TRNN's Jessica Desvarieux speaks with Pace University's Chris Williams and IPS' Janet Redman about the Vatican's contradictory policy in light of the Pope's call to fight climate change.
link_name: Top Pope Advisor Says Vatican Will Not Divest From Fossil Fuels

status_message:
"It really leads to the conclusion that they just are against women's sexual agency and sexual autonomy and reproductive autonomy, and want women to go back to the days where they just had a lot of babies and didn't have much say in the matter." - Patricia Miller

Author Patricia Miller discusses how Pope Francis's position on the abolition of the death penalty versus the abolition of abortion deprives conservatives an advantage on social justice issues.
link_name: What Pope Francis' Call to Abolish Death Penalty Could Mean For Republicans

status_message: "We want everyone to understand and feel the crisis that we feel. And so we're not going to let things just happen as usual. That is part of American political tradition, that is what civil disobedience is all about. "
link_name: Prosecutors Drop False Imprisonment Charges Against Baltimore Pastor

status_message:
"You can't preach about inequality, you can't preach about poverty and trying to make people flourish and happy while saying that women are somehow secondary." - Miriam Duignan

TRNN's Thomas Hedges covers a die-in staged by excommunicated priests to protest the Pope's refusal to allow women into priesthood.
link_name: Priests to Pope: Stop the Sexism

status_message:
"FARC has been placed in a position where they know that they have absolutely no chance of winning a military victory. They've abandoned that course of action. And so the only realistic option left open to them is negotiation."

Universidad de EAFIT Professor, Joshua Large discusses the details of the Peace agreement, the weakening of the FARC and the current state of Colombian politics.
link_name: War Crimes and Land Reform in the Colombian Agreement with FARC

status_message: "When you ask what we as victims want, you know, nothing can give us back our innocence and our childhood that was taken from us. We can't go back and grow up over again. But it would mean the world to us to know that maybe the other 12 and 13-year-olds are not getting raped like we were when we were children. And that's the most important thing for us as victims." - Barbara Blaine, founder and president of SNAP, Survivors Network of those Abused by Priests.
link_name: The Pope is Dishonest About Zero Tolerance for Child Sex Abuse

status_message:
"Gore Vidal...famously said that the American economic system is capitalism for the workers and socialism for the rich", Ha-Joon Chang explains why in the third installment of the 23 Things They Don't Tell You About Capitalism.

Ha-Joon Chang also believes that most people in rich countries are paid more than they should be. Do you agree?
link_name: 23 Things They Don't Tell You About Capitalism Pt.3

status_message:
TRNN Replay: As Saudi ground troops enter Northern Yemen with US backing, Amnesty International charges Saudis with alleged war crimes. We hear from Vijay Prashad about the ongoing struggle to hold nations accountable for their complicity in the death of civilians.

"In the middle of this conflict, which Amnesty International has said that the Saudis are committing alleged war crimes, in the middle of all this the United States has resupplied Saudi Arabia with the very weapons they're using against the Yemeni people." - Vijay Prashad
link_name: Extraordinary Brutality Inflicted on Civilians in Yemen

status_message: ICYMI: "That's how involved the United States was, literally naming people that had to be executed in the concentration camps." - Carmen Aguirre, the Author of Fierce: Memoirs of a Revolutionary Daughter.
link_name: Daughter of The Revolution

status_message:
"We want to stop the killing. We want to stop the now increasing destabilization of some key allies by all these refugees that are heading out of Syria. We want to get the situation under control, stabilize it, and somehow turn it around so it's more positive. It also will impact Iraq. It will impact Afghanistan. And ultimately it will impact this growing rapprochement with Iran, which can handle a lot more of these problems." - Col. Lawrence Wilkerson

Col. Lawrence Wilkerson tells Paul Jay that cooperation with Russia and Iran is the only way to resolve the situation, but U.S. policy is catering to Saudi Arabian, Turkish and Israeli ambitions.
link_name: Is the U.S. Secretly Welcoming Increased Russian Syria Involvement?

status_message:
Pope Francis spoke today in D.C. about the U.S. prison system. Here's a replay of our recent story about the landmark court decision to stop solitary confinement in California prisons. 

"Every life is sacred, every human person is endowed with an inalienable dignity, and society can only benefit from the rehabilitation of those convicted of crimes." - Pope Francis
link_name: In Landmark Ruling, California Prisons Halt Solitary Confinement

status_message: "The problem with the financial market of today is not that it is inefficient, but it's too efficient, but efficient for the wrong things, efficient in creating speculative gains, efficient in moving money around basically for the sake of making profit rather than, you know, channeling it to long-term productive investment." - Ha-Joon Chang
link_name: 23 Things They Don't Tell You About Capitalism Pt.8

status_message: "It seems that for all of the regional powers that are interested in what is unfolding in Syria...the only tool in their toolbox seems to be weaponry and military intervention. And...for the past four years now [this] has not served to reduce the levels of violence [and] has not allowed the people of Syria any chance of living a normal life." - Shir Hever says Netanyahu made misleading statements after his trip to Russia about coordinated military action in Syria.
link_name: Netanyahu Meets Putin Looking for Existential Threat to Israel

status_message: "For us as victims, what we are looking for is concrete action on the part of the pope. We just don't want any more children to suffer as we did. And we believe that children remain at risk today, so we think that Pope Francis should clearly state that all sexual perpetrators have to be removed from the priesthood. They shouldn't get to keep their jobs, and yet they do." - Barbara Blaine, founder and president of SNAP, Survivors Network of those Abused by Priests.
link_name: The Pope is Dishonest About Zero Tolerance for Child Sex Abuse

status_message:
"When you see what happened in Pocomoke, where the African-American community had rallied around this chief who is African-American and the white community, especially the white leaders, have said...we're not going to tell you anything and don't make a big stink about it, you can see that the sort of racism and the racial mistrust is deep rooted down there."

TRRN's Taya Graham and Stephen Janis say city officials' reactions to black community's calls for accountability reveal the depth of racial divisions in this small eastern shore town.
link_name: What the Firing of Pocomoke's First Black Police Chief Tells about Race in the US

status_message:
"We're taking the 1 percent that can't get it anywhere else, by and large, and we're putting them in the military. And we're putting upon them the burden of defending this nation. Defending the other 320-some odd million people in this country who don't have any skin in the game at all. When you have congressmen with no skin in the game, when you have business leaders, corporate leaders, others, religious leaders, no skin in the game, then you have the ability to go to war without any real restraint on you."

Col. Larry Wilkerson, former chief of staff to United States Secretary of State Colin Powell, expounds on the book Skin In the Game, by Gen. Dennis Laich.
link_name: Skin In the Game: Poor Kids and Patriots

status_message:
"We're all Greeks now and we're all having austerity rammed down our throat. We're reconfiguring the global economy into a kind of form of neo-feudalism. So what does it mean to have revolution?" - Chris Hedges

In this episode of teleSUR's Days of Revolt, host Chris Hedges sits down with author and professor Leo Panitch to discuss how global imperialism and capitalism are upheld by economic and cultural forces, and debate the roles of ignorance, myth, and malevolence in the perpetuation of systems of inequality. Join the debate here and let us know what you think.
link_name: Days of Revolt: The Making of Global Capitalism

status_message:
"As a matter of fact this war has kind of given al-Qaeda a human face on the ground. al-Qaeda in Yemen is no longer an extremist group that is threatening everyone. They kind of now appear as if they are another local actor engaged in this war. Because in this war they have effectively fought alongside the allies temporarily."

Sama'a Al-Hamdani a policy expert on Yemen, says it's in the interest of all parties to achieve a political solution as soon as possible because the alternative may be far worse.
link_name: Yemeni Government Returns from Exile as al-Qaeda Expands Foothold

status_message:
"The saddest example is a woman named Candice Anderson, she's in Texas. She lost control of her Saturn and ran into a tree, killing her fiancee. And she was charged with reckless homicide for that accident. And it turned out later that the car had a defective switch, and the judge expunged all of her criminal record, but not before her parents had to liquidate their retirement account to pay for her defense."

Professor Rena Steinzor on one of the 124 deaths tied to the corporation's faulty ignition switches, for which General Motors agreed to pay a $900 million settlement.
link_name: Legal Expert Says DOJ Should Have Criminally Prosecuted General Motors

status_message:
"The commercial banks are now holding $2.5 trillion in cash. They get the money for free because the interest rate is zero. They're holding the equivalent of 15 percent of U.S. GDP in cash. And they're not lending it out. The whole point of the policy is not just for the banks to accumulate cash, but to lend it." - Robert Pollin

Robert Pollin says the Federal Reserve has the tools to promote credit expansion for productive investment and create jobs for 22 million people who are currently out of work.
link_name: Here is How the Fed Can Really Stimulate the Economy?

status_message:
"I think his role as a religious leader, not as pope but as a religious leader, as a person of integrity, is to judge in a positive way all those instances where he sees love. And insofar as those of us who are lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender are loving, then in fact we should be judged and judged positively."

Feminist theologian Mary E. Hunt discusses whether the hype around the Pope's visit deserves the unbridled enthusiasm of the media and progressive community.

status_message:
"In the last 30 years, the top 1 percent of the Americans who used to take about 10 percent of national income back in 1979 has come to claim something like 23 percent of national income. So their share increased by almost two and a half times." Ha-Joon Chang

Ha-Joon Chang speaks with Paul Jay about how Americans have given a huge amount of extra income to these people who are supposed to make everyone richer, but they have done it for nothing.
link_name: 23 Things They Don't Tell You About Capitalism Pt.6

In Part 5 Ha-Joon Chang dispels the myth of U.S. preeminence and the belief that the private sector can always do a better job than the government. 

"Singapore Airline, which is one of the most...highly rated airline companies in the world, is actually a fully state-owned enterprise. In the nearly 40 years of its operation, it has never made one penny of loss. In contrast, all the free enterprise American airline companies live on government subsidies."
link_name: 23 Things They Don't Tell You About Capitalism Pt.5

status_message:
"As a matter of fact this war has kind of given al-Qaeda a human face on the ground. al-Qaeda in Yemen is no longer an extremist group that is threatening everyone. They kind of now appear as if they are another local actor engaged in this war. Because in this war they have effectively fought alongside the allies temporarily."

status_message:
"This notion that somehow you have a service sector that is strong and big enough to finance your manufacturing demand is completely based on myth...Countries like Switzerland that you think live on taking care of dirty money deposited by third world dictators...in per capita terms, is the most industrialized economy in the world."

Ha-Joon Chang explains, in this fourth installment of 23 Things They Don't Tell You About Capitalism, why he believes that we do not live in a post-industrial age.
link_name: 23 Things They Don't Tell You About Capitalism Pt.4

status_message:
RESISTENCIA: A Special Screening of a Thrilling Documentary on the Resistance to a Honduran Coup

EVENT DETAILS:

"When a 21st century coup d'tat ousts the only president they ever believed in, these farmers take over the plantations. With no plans to ever give them back."

After being shown at festivals worldwide, this groundbreaking documentary on the resistance to the 2009 Honduran coup d'tat is coming to Baltimore. Filmmaker Jesse Freeston will be with us to lead a post-film discussion.

TRAILER: resistenciathefilm.com/trailer

"Freeston's extensive footage from post-coup Aguan transmits the collective excitement that comes with reclaiming the right to a dignified existence." - Beln Fernndez, Warscapes

For more reviews see: resistenciathefilm.com/reviews

THE FILM: 

June 28th 2009, the first coup d'tat in a generation in Central America overthrows the elected president of Honduras. A nationwide resistance movement is born, which takes inspiration from the daring act of the farmers of the Aguan Valley to take over 10,000 acres of palm oil plantations claimed by the country's largest landowner, and a key player in the coup. Filmed over four years beginning with the coup itself, 'Resistencia: The Fight for the Aguan Valley' follows three key members of the farmers' resistance as they convert the plantations into a workers co-op and agitate for a more democratic state, all while trying to survive the violent reaction of the landlord and the coup regime.

PRESENTED BY THE REAL NEWS @ THE BALTIMORE STUDIOS:

231 Holliday Street,
Baltimore, MD 21202

October 5, 2015

6:30PM - Doors Open
7-8:30PM - Film Screening
8:30-9:30PM - Q&A Reception

$5 SUGGESTED DONATION

This event is proudly brought to you by: therealnews.com

FOLLOW US ON SOCIAL MEDIA HERE: 

www.facebook.com/therealnews
www.twitter.com/therealnews
link_name: RESISTENCIA: THE FIGHT FOR THE AGUAN VALLEY

status_message:
Actvism Munich & The Real News Network aim to surface & dissect generalizations, which are routinely reiterated by the political & corporate-media establishment, through in-depth analysis & discussions that bring into light an historical and economic context.

In our opinion, generalizations include labeling people under a national character ("The tax-evading & lazy Greeks") or attaching specific set of characteristics to certain communities, religions, sects, gender, races, etc while ignoring exceptions and examples that prove otherwise - this approach in our opinion serves certain interests in society that are essential for the public to know to make informed decisions.

Like & invite your Facebook network to stay in touch with our analysis:
acTVism Munich: www.facebook.com/acTVism
The Real News Network: www.facebook.com/therealnews

status_message:
It's easy to say that the judicial system is broken. What's more difficult, and often lost, is listening to people like Bobbi Smallwood, whose son was famously given a $500,000 bail for smashing in a police car window during the Baltimore uprisings, talk about the pain of being caught up in that system.

Last week, her son's trial was set to begin but instead, not only was the trial postponed but Smallwood's husband, Maurice, was arrested after muttering that the case was bullshit. 

We found Smallwood crouched and crying in one of the hallways in the court house building while her husband sat across from her in handcuffs. It turns out they couldn't arrest him for what he said under his breath, so they arrested him instead for wearing a hat in the court room.

"I go for open-heart surgery Monday," Smallwood said in a broken voice, and "because my son and my husband" are locked up, "I can't go. I got so much stress on me."

"This system is gone," she said. "This world is going to an end. It's so bad that before I go to bed at night, I pray to God that I don't even wake up the next morning 'cause I can't take it. I'm tired. I'm literally dying."

Listen to Smallwood talk about a system that mostly poor, black and hispanic families deal with every day:
link_name: A Broken System Breaks Families

status_message: Next Saturday, August 29th, The Real News will be hosting an event at Baltimore Studios in downtown Baltimore. The event will be a special screening of the film short Releasing the Dragon: A Tribute to George Jackson and Black August. If you're not familiar with his story you can read about it in the event details. Following the screening there will be a special audience Q&A centered around one of Jackson's key statements on building a viable revolution. Follow Actvism Munich & The Real News Network to stay updated with news that tracks terrorist attacks worldwide and analysis that provides a historical & economic context to them.

"Terrorism is on the rise, with an almost fivefold increase in fatalities since 9/11, in spite of US-led efforts to combat it in the Middle East and elsewhere around the world, according to a report published on Tuesday.

The Global Terrorism Index recorded almost 18,000 deaths in 2014, a jump of about 60% over the previous year.

The "war on terror" launched by the Bush administration after the 2001 attacks on New York and Washington has failed to eliminate or reduce terrorism in spite of Washington having spent $4.4tn (2.8tn) on the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and operations elsewhere." - (The Guardian, Global Terrorism Index)

status_message:
Exclusive: Protestors place a #BlackLivesMatter poster on a Confederate War Memorial on the grounds of a courthouse in Easton, Maryland. 

Activists note that Talbot County Council agreed to also create a statue of famed-abolitionist Frederick Douglass in 2011, but under the condition it be placed lower then the Confederate Memorial. Known as one of the most powerful orators of the 19th Century, Frederick Douglass was born into slavery a few miles outside of Easton. He went on to be a leading figure in the fight to end slavery in the United States and lobbied President Abraham Lincoln to not concede to the Confederacy during the early years of the Civil War.

status_message:
Actvism Munich & The Real News Network aim to provide "contextual" news & analysis that is premised on reason and facts. Instead of following the corporate method, which is to surface events hastily without due diligence and context (historical, economic, etc) with the primary goal of maximizing short-term profit, we carefully dissect, analyse and rigorously debate events & issues with the underlying aim of advancing understanding & participation.

With so many developments unfolding around the globe, we believe that news & analysis should be approached with scrutiny and utmost sincerity, a process that requires patience, and may perhaps delay our coverage, but nevertheless provides an objective and contextual assessment of political, economic & social developments.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
I Mix What I Like Screening - Releasing the Dragon: A Tribute to George Jackson and Black August

Saturday August 29, 2015 6:30pm-9:30pm

FREE

Breakout Groups With Audience Participation
Hosted by: Jared Ball & Bashi Rose

Background: On January 12, 1960, George Jackson was sentenced to one year to life for a $70 gas station robbery. He would serve eleven years and seven months, with seven of those years in solitary confinement. On August 21, 1971, he was assassinated.

In the intervening years, Jackson penned two centerpieces of revolutionary canonical texts: Soledad Brother and Blood In My Eye. In this screening, you will see and hear Jackson's ideas spoken, performed, and reflected by artists, activists, comrades, loved ones and the people to whom he spoke who now speak him back to us.
link_name: I Mix What I Like Screening - Releasing the Dragon: A Tribute to George Jackson and Black August

This is a deal to keep Iran from sometime in the future, if they decided to, which they have not decided to yet according to the CIA, the Mossad, and all 16 U.S. intelligence agencies, decide to make a nuclear weapon. status_message: TONIGHT!! on Awake Radio at 6pm EST will be Marshall "Eddie" Conway from The Real News Network. Marshall Edward ("Eddie") Conway is a former member of the Black Panther Party who was falsely imprisoned for a crime he did not commit. Eddie was falsely implicated in the murder of one Baltimore City police officer and the assault and attempted murder of two other officers. Eddie claims that not only is he innocent, but that he was a target of the FBI's Counterintelligence Program (COINTELPRO), a program designed to destroy individuals and organizations that were considered to be politically objectionable. Eddie asserts that he is one of many political prisoners in the United States as a result of F.B.I. Director J. Edgar Hoover's and Assistant Director William Sullivan's war against the Black Panther Party. Eddie was part of a panel at the Left Forum this weekend entitled; Against the Narrative, Independent Media and the Left. Check it out!
link_name: awakeradio

status_message:
We're hiring for Social Media interns! Email stephen@therealnews.com if you're interested.

The Producer of Social Media will provide one-on-one mentorship and supervision to help interns maximize their educational experience. (Where possible, The Real News will provide assistance to interns requesting academic or work-study credit.) The Internship program is offered in three sessions per year with 3-5 intern placements each session. Interns will be working with our Social Media Department.

Internships are unpaid, 10-15 hours per week, temporary work placements to help people in school, people who are just finishing school and people starting a new career to gain valuable skill sets and experience in the following fields of social media, outreach, and fundraising, in a non-profit setting. All internships take place at our Baltimore studio where we produce the show.

status_message:
The Real News Network is looking for a new Membership Relations Organizer to join our team! We're looking for an individual with some experience in organizing. Must be very familiar with our content and skilled at developing one-to-one relationships. To apply, send a resume, 2-3 references, writing sample and a cover letter to jobs@therealnews.com! 

Job Responsibilities:

    Membership Relations engaging and expanding the TRNN membership while exponentially increasing their contributions
    Project manage quarterly fundraising campaigns including ask emails, producing pitch videos and ensuring campaign targets are met or exceeded
    Identify, develop and maintain relationships with member donors for the purpose of securing and sustaining a strong donor community for The Real News Network
    Work with the CEO to strengthen our fundraising strategies
    Produce a weekly donor report for executive team
    Identify member relations training needs at TRNN and deliver training sessions to individuals and groups of volunteers
    Communicate with donors via phone, email, social media and in person
    Coordinate with the social media manager to ensure message continuity
    Keep update on all Real News stories
    Coordinate all premium and gift functions
    Event Management including creating a communication plan, designing invites, posters, etc., and coordinating actual events
    Manage staffing needs for events coordinate volunteers
    Be the point person for all communications between departments
    Perform additional duties as assigned 

JOB REQUIREMENTS

Education and Experience:

* Associate's Degree in related field.

    Minimum of 1 year relevant work experience. May include membership relations in a nonprofit, student organizing, labor and/or community organizing or another relevant field.
    Must have experienced in fundraising, implementing online campaigns, Product Marketing, Membership, Technology, Operations, Project Management and Design.
    Experience in utilizing a CRM to manage members (Click and Pledge, Salesforce, etc.)
    Experience in Marketing (traditional, new media, guerilla, and word of mouth)
    Experience in Design Intermediate ability to use design tools in adobe creative suite. 

Skills and Abilities:

* Must have a demonstrated track record in fundraising, donor relations, volunteer outreach and event management.

    Proven creativity in raising funds.
    Excellent communication skills in both verbal and written.
    Must have advanced knowledge of MS Word and Excel
    Must be eager to communicate by phone and be persuasive.
    Ability to organize and have the willingness to experiment.
    Ability to contribute individually, and lead, manage, or participate in cross-functional teams
    Must have doggedness, determination and a sense of humor.
    Ability to synthesize large amounts of data into actionable information.
    Ability to create great working relationships with all levels within the company and across multiple disciplines.

status_message:
CLARIFICATION: The original version of this story referred to the documents showing a pattern of harassment in March.  The arrests cited in the story occurred prior to the death of Freddie Gray.  

Exclusive documents obtained by The Real News show how police officers engaged in a pattern of abuse before the killing of Freddie Gray by arresting teenagers who were waiting to take the bus back home. Days later, that very place in Northwest Baltimore would erupt and lead to the chaos seen this week.
link_name: BREAKING: Police Were Harassing Students Before Monday's Outrage

status_message: Update: New developments today on a story The Real News Network has been covering in Baltimore. Community activists and environmental advocates expressed relief after the city severed ties with a planned downtown incinerator that would convert trash into energy. On Wednesday The Board of Estimates voted unanimously to cancel a $1 million contract with Energy Answers International Inc. through the Baltimore Regional Cooperative Purchasing Cooperative. The mayor said lack of progress with the project forced her hand.
link_name: 'Facts Don't Matter' Community Faces Health Risks from New Incinerator (3/4)

status_message: Today in partnership with the organization South Organizing Against Racism (SOAR), the Real News will look at specific short-term solutions to hold police officers more accountable. The doors will open at 4:00pm and close at 5:00pm. The first show will take place from 5:30-6:30 PM. The doors will open at 4:00pm and close at 5:00pm. We will debate the merits of enforcing mandatory body cameras for all officers and conducting independent investigations with no affiliations to local police departments. In our second hour, we will look at the meaning of these demonstrations in this point of time and what lessons can be learned from previous generations concerning long-term strategies to drive the movement or moment forward.
link_name: SOAR Presents: Police Violence and Militarization Town Hall

status_message:
In partnership with the organization South Organizing Against Racism (SOAR), the Real News will look at specific short-term solutions to hold police officers more accountable. The doors will open at 4:00pm and close at 5:00pm. The first show will take place from 5:30-6:30 PM. The doors will open at 4:00pm and close at 5:00pm. We will debate the merits of enforcing mandatory body cameras for all officers and conducting independent investigations with no affiliations to local police departments. In our second hour, we will look at the meaning of these demonstrations in this point of time and what lessons can be learned from previous generations concerning long-term strategies to drive the movement or moment forward. 

Please keep in mind that this is not a Baltimore-specific discussion, and we would like to go further with our discussion from our previous town hall and put these solutions in a national context. 

About SOAR (South Organizing Against Racism)  We are linking up youth, youth led programs and organizations across the south and beyond who are interested in creating a world driven by peace and justice where we can create a sustainable economic, environmental and political system that saves the future of our planet.

LINK TO EVENT: http://soar.afsc.org/

status_message:
In partnership with the organization South Organizing Against Racism (SOAR), the Real News will look at specific short-term solutions to hold police officers more accountable. The doors will open at 4:00pm and close at 5:00pm. The first show will take place from 5:30-6:30 PM. The doors will open at 4:00pm and close at 5:00pm. We will debate the merits of enforcing mandatory body cameras for all officers and conducting independent investigations with no affiliations to local police departments. In our second hour, we will look at the meaning of these demonstrations in this point of time and what lessons can be learned from previous generations concerning long-term strategies to drive the movement or moment forward. 

Please keep in mind that this is not a Baltimore-specific discussion, and we would like to go further with our discussion from our previous town hall and put these solutions in a national context. 

About SOAR (South Organizing Against Racism)  We are linking up youth, youth led programs and organizations across the south and beyond who are interested in creating a world driven by peace and justice where we can create a sustainable economic, environmental and political system that saves the future of our planet.

LINK TO EVENT: http://soar.afsc.org/
link_name: SOAR Presents: Police Violence and Militarization Town Hall
